title: Early anglo-saxon grotesque à la Bureau Grot
content:
Here's a typeface that a major German magazine has been using for a while. An old-school grotesque in the vein of the [Stephenson Blake](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417090723/http:/a1.dspnimg.com/data/l/2085910623030_Rp8aLgvk_l.jpg) ones which have seen [several](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417090723/http:/www.aisforapple.fr/fonts/grotesque-6/) [revivals](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417090723/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/BureauGrot/) [during](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417090723/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/grotesque-no-9/) [the past few years.](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417090723/http:/www.stormtype.com/family-trivia-grotesk.html) ...all of which I've had a close look at, but this is none of them. Note the rather tame /Q/ in contrast to most of the ones I mentioned. The /t/ is a good shibboleth too. The /g/, not shown here, is of course double-storey. Yes, it could be a custom typeface, but then again, none of the four other faces that they use (AG, Sabon, Freight) is.

[![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417090723im_/http:/i.imgur.com/HgQZAbE.png "Hosted by imgur.com")](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417090723/http:/imgur.com/HgQZAbE)

Font: 

 Founders Grotesk

 [Renko](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417090723/http:/typophile.com/user/12000 "View user profile.")
